children.name: Module 1
children.enum1: I. Effect and Application of Laws
children.enum2: II. Human Relations (19-36, New Civil Code)

children.name: I. Effect and Application of Laws
Arts. 1-10
children.details: CHAPTER 1: Effect and Application of Laws

children.name: Article 2
children.enum1: Laws shall take effect after fifteen days following the completion of their publication in the Official Gazette, unless it is otherwise provided. This Code shall take effect one year after such publication.

children.name: Requisites for a Newspaper to be of General Circulation
children.enum1: 1) Subscription
children.enum2: 2) Daily Publication
children.enum3: 3) Reach is not Limited to a Locality, but throughout the Philippines

children.name: 1. Tanada v. Tuvera
children.details: All statutes, including  those of local application  and private  laws, shall be published as a condition for their effectivity, which shall begin fifteen days after publication unless a different effectivity date is fixed by the legislature.

children.name: 2. De Roy v. Court of Appeals
children.details: There is no law requiring the publication of Supreme Court decisions in the  Official  Gazette  before  they  can  be  binding  and  as  a condition to their becoming effective.

children.name: 3. People vs., Que Po Lay
children.details: Circulars and regulations especially like the Circular No. 20 of the Central Bank in question which prescribes a penalty for its violation should be published  before  becoming  effective,  this,  on  the  general principle and theory that before the public is bound by its contents, especially its penal provisions, a law, regulation or circular must first be published and the people officially and specifically informed of said contents and its penalties.

children.name: 4. NPC v. Pinatubo Commercial
children.details: Interpretative  regulations  and those merely internal in nature, that is, regulating only the personnel of the administrative agency and not the public, need not be published.

children.name: 5. Neri vs. Senate Committee on Accountability of Public Officers
children.details: The Senate Rules of Procedure Governing Inquiries in Aid of Legislation must be published. But not required to be in Official Gazette or a newspaper of general circulation.

children.name: 6. Pimentel v. SENATE COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE
children.details: Publication is required for the Rules of the Senate Committee of the Whole to be effective by virtue of its own provision, not by the publication requirement under the civil code.

children.name: Article 4
children.enum1: Laws shall have no retroactive effect, unless the contrary is provided.

children.name: 7. Valeroso v. People
children.details: As a general  rule,  penal  laws should  not have  retroactive  application,  lest they acquire the character  of an ex post facto  law.  An exception  to this rule,  however,  is when  the law  is advantageous to the accused.

children.name: 8. PNB v. Office of the President
children.details: While P.D. 957 did not expressly provide for retroactivity in its entirety, yet the same can be plainly  inferred  from the unmistakable  intent  of the law to protect innocent  lot buyers  from scheming subdivision developers.

children.name: 9. Commissioner of Internal Revenue v. Philippine Health Care Providers, Inc.,
children.details: Section 246 of the 1997 Tax Code, as amended, provides that any revocation, modification or reversal of rulings, circulars, rules and regulations promulgated by the CIR have no retroactive application  if it would prejudice  the taxpayer.  The exceptions  to this rule are: (1) where the taxpayer deliberately misstates or omits material facts from his return or in any document required of him by the BIR; (2) where the facts subsequently gathered by the BIR are materially differ ent from the facts on which the ruling is based, or (3) where the taxpayer acted in bad faith.

children.name: Article 6
children.enum1: Rights may be waived, unless the waiver is contrary to law, public order, public policy, morals, or good customs, or prejudicial to a third person with a right recognized by law.

children.name: 10. D.M. Consunji vs. CA
children.details: The choice of a party between inconsistent remedies results in a waiver by election. Where one lacks knowledge of a right,  there  is no  basis upon  which waiver  of  it  can  rest. Ignorance  of  a  material  fact  negates waiver, and waiver cannot be established by a consent given under a mistake or misapprehension of fact. It bears stressing that what negates waiver is lack of knowledge  or a mistake of fact.

children.name: Article 5
children.enum1: Acts executed against the provisions of mandatory or prohibitory laws shall be void, except when the law itself authorizes their validity.

children.name: 11. Cui vs. Arellano University
children.details: In order to declare a contract void as against public policy, a court must find that the contract as to consideration or the thing to be done, contravenes some established interest of society, or is inconsistent with sound policy and good morals or tends clearly to undermine the security of individual  rights.

children.name: Article 7
children.enum1: Laws are repealed only by subsequent ones, and their violation or non-observance shall not be excused by disuse, or custom or practice to the contrary.
children.enum2: When the courts declared a law to be inconsistent with the Constitution, the former shall be void and the latter shall govern.
children.enum3: Administrative or executive acts, orders and regulations shall be valid only when they are not contrary to the laws or the Constitution.

children.name: 12. Mecano v. COA
children.details: Repeals  of statutes by implication are not favored. The presumption is against inconsistency and repugnancy for the legislature is presumed to know the existing laws on the subject and not to have  enacted inconsistent or conflicting statutes.

children.name: Article 8
children.enum1: Judicial decisions applying or interpreting the laws or the Constitution shall form a part of the legal system of the Philippines.

children.name: 13. People v. Licera
children.details: Article 8 of the Civil Code decrees that judicial decisions applying or interpreting the laws or the Constitution form part of this jurisdiction's legal system. These decisions, although in themselves not laws, constitute evidence of what the laws mean. The application or interpretation placed by the Court upon a law is part of the law as of the date of the enactment of the said law since the Court's application or interpretation  merely establishes the contemporaneous  legislative intent that the construed law purports to carry into effect.

children.name: 14. Chu Jan vs. Bernas
children.details: Foreseeing that a case might arise to which no law would be exactly applicable, the Civil Code, in the second paragraph of article 6 (now Art. 11), provides that the customs of the place shall be observed, and, in the absence thereof, the general principles of law.

children.name: 15. People vs. Purisima
children.issue: Should the Whereas clauses of the law be considered in the determination of the intent of the law?
children.ruling: YES
children.details: Legislative intent must be ascertained from a consideration of the statute as a whole, and not of an isolated part or a particular provision alone. This is a cardinal rule of statutory construction. For taken in the abstract, a word or phrase might easily convey a meaning quite different from the one actually intended and evident when the word or phrase is considered with those with which it is associated. Thus, an apparently general provision may have a limited application if read together with other provisions.

children.name: Association of International Shipping Lines, Inc. v. Secretary of Finance
children.details: RR here which is internal in nature need not be published.

children.name: 1. Martinez vs. Van Buskirk
children.issue: Is the cochero of the defendant negligent in leaving the horses in the manner described by the evidence in this case?
children.ruling: No. The act of defendant's driver in leaving the horses in the manner proved was not unreasonable or imprudent.
children.details: Acts, the performance of which has not proved destructive or injurious and which have, therefore, been acquiesced in by society for so long a time that they have ripened into custom, cannot be held to be themselves unreasonable or imprudent.

children.name: 2. Yao Kee vs. Sy-Gonzales
children.facts: Mano Po without the marriage certificate.
children.issue: Is the validity of the marriage of Sy Kiat to Yao Kee in accordance with Chinese law and customs on marriage conclusive?
children.ruling: No.
children.details: Custom is defined as a rule of conduct formed by repetition of acts, uniformly observed (practiced) as a social rule, legally binding and obligatory. The law requires that a custom must be proved as a fact, according to the rules of evidence [Article 12, Civil Code.]

children.name: 3. CIR vs. Primetown
children.details: a Year shall be understood to be twelve calendar months and the number of days is irrelevant.

children.name: 4. Van Dorn vs. Ronillo, Jr. et al.,
children.issue: Is the divorce decree obtained by an alien abroad valid and binding in the Philippines even if it is contrary to local law and public policy?
children.ruling: Pursuant to his national law, private respondent is no longer the husband of petitioner. He would have no standing to sue in the case below as petitioner's husband entitled to exercise control over conjugal assets.
children.details: aliens may obtain divorces abroad, which may be recognized in the Philippines, provided they are valid according to their national law.

children.name: 5. Pilapil vs. Ibay-Somera
children.issue: May an alien file a complaint for adultery after obtaining a divorce decree abroad?
children.ruling: No.
children.details: After a divorce has been decreed, the innocent spouse no longer has the right to institute proceedings against the offenders.

children.name: 6. San Luis v. San Luis
children.issue: May a Filipino who is divorced by his alien spouse abroad validly remarry?
children.details: If the foreigner obtains a valid foreign divorce, the Filipino spouse shall have capacity to remarry under Philippine law.

children.name: II. Human Relations (19-36, New Civil Code)
1. Uypitching vs. Quiamco
children.issue: Should petitioners be held liable for damages despite the claim that their action is merely exercise of their right as seller-mortgagee to foreclose mortgage in case of default?
children.ruling: Yes, petitioners should be held liable. Petitioner corporation failed to bring the proper civil action necessary to acquire legal possession of the motorcycle. Instead, petitioner Uypitching descended on respondent's establishment with his policemen and ordered the seizure of the motorcycle without a search warrant or court order.
children.details: The motorcycle thief is the mortgagee. Article 19, also known as the principle of abuse of right, prescribes that a person should not use his right unjustly or contrary to honesty and good faith, otherwise he opens himself to liability. It seeks to preclude the use of, or the tendency to use, a legal right (or duty) as a means to unjust ends.

children.name: 2. Wassmer vs. Velez
children.issue: Was the breach of Velez in his promise to marry Wassmer constitute an actionable wrong provided that the wedding was formally set and elaborate preparations for the same were made?
children.ruling: Yes, Velez is liable to Wassmer for damages. As stated, mere breach of promise to marry is not an actionable wrong. It must not be overlooked, however, that the extent to which acts not contrary to law may be perpetrated with impunity, is not limitless for Article 21 of said Code provides that any person who wilfully causes loss or injury to another in a manner that is contrary to morals, good customs or public policy shall compensate the latter for the damage.
children.details: MERE BREACH OF PROMISE TO MARRY IS NOT AN ACTIONABLE WRONG; BUT TO FORMALLY SET A WEDDING AND GO THROUGH ALL THE ABOVE-DESCRIBED PREPARATION AND PUBLICITY, ONLY TO WALK OUT OF IT WHEN THE MATRIMONY IS ABOUT TO BE SOLEMNIZED, IS QUITE DIFFERENT

children.name: 3. Nikko Hotel Manila Garden
children.facts: Reyes filed a complaint for damages based on Article 19 and 21 of the New Civil Code. Lim and Hotel Nikko contend that pursuant to the doctrine of volenti non fit injuria, they cannot be made liable for damages as respondent Reyes assumed the risk of being asked to leave (and being embarrassed and humiliated in the process) as he was a gate-crasher.
children.issue: Does Ms. Lim’s treatment to Reyes give rise for an action for damages against the latter and the hotel based on Articles 19 and 21 of the New Civil Code?
children.details: THE EXERCISE OF A LEGAL RIGHT OR DUTY IN GOOD FAITH AND WITH NO INTENTION TO PREJUDICE OR INJURE ANOTHER WILL NOT GIVE RISE TO AN ACTION FOR DAMAGES

children.name: 4. Gashem Shookat Baksh vs. CA
children.issue: Was the petitioner’s breach of promise to marry contrary to morals, good customs, and public policy so as to entitle private respondent to the award of damages?
children.ruling: Yes. where a man's promise to marry is in fact the proximate cause of the acceptance of his love by a woman and his representation to fulfill that promise thereafter becomes the proximate cause of the giving of herself unto him in a sexual congress, proof that he had, in reality, no intention of marrying her and that the promise was only a subtle scheme or deceptive device to entice or inveigle her to accept him and to obtain her consent to the sexual act, could justify the award of damages pursuant to Article 21 not because of such promise to marry but because of the fraud and deceit behind it and the willful injury to her honor and reputation which followed thereafter.
children.details: FRAUD AND DECEIT BEHIND BREACH OF PROMISE TO MARRY ENTITLES THE PLAINTIFF TO RECOVER DAMAGES

children.name: 5. Pe vs. Pe
children.facts: The respondent frequented the house of Lolita on the pretext that he wanted to teach her how to pray the rosary. They fell in love with each other and conducted clandestine trysts.  The  rumors  about  their  love  affairs  reached  Lolita’s  parents  and  the respondent was forbidden from further seeing Lolita. Their love affair continued nonetheless. Lolita later disappeared from their residence. Her family found a handwritten note from the defendant to Lolita regarding the date of their meeting.
children.issue: Are the petitioners entitled to recover moral, compensatory, exemplary and corrective damages based on Article 21 of the Civil Code for the acts of the respondent?
children.ruling: Yes, the petitioners are entitled to recover damages for the acts of respondent.
children.details: DAMAGES CAN BE RECOVERED BY THE FAMILY IF THE INJURY IS CAUSED IN A MANNER CONTRARY TO MORALS, GOOD CUSTOMS, AND PUBLIC POLICY

children.name: 6. Globe Mackay Cable vs. CA
children.issue: Should petitioners be held liable for damages for the imputation of guilt and harassment during the investigations despite its claim of lawful exercise of its right to dismiss employee?
children.ruling: Yes. Petitioners should be held liable for damages.
children.details: The imputation of guilt without basis and the pattern of harassment during the investigations of Tobias transgressed the standards of human conduct set forth in Article 19 of the Civil Code. The Court has already ruled that the right of the employer to dismiss an employee should not be confused with the manner in which the right is exercised and the effects flowing therefrom. If the dismissal is done abusively, then the employer is liable for damages to the employee.

children.name: 7. University of the East vs. Jader
children.issue: May a university be held liable for damages for misleading a student into believing that the latter had satisfied all the requirements for graduation?
children.ruling: Yes. UE may be held liable. Considering that the institution of learning involved herein is a university which is engaged in legal education, it should have practiced what it inculcates in its students, more specifically the principle of good dealings enshrined in Articles 19 and 20 of the Civil Code. Educational institutions are duty-bound to inform the students of their academic status and not wait for the latter to inquire from the former.
children.details: When one of two innocent parties must suffer, he through whose agency the loss occurred must bear it. The modern tendency is to grant indemnity for damages in cases where there is abuse of right, even when the act is not illicit. If mere fault or negligence in one’s acts can make him liable for damages for injury caused thereby, with more reason should abuse or bad faith make him liable. A person should be protected only when he acts in the legitimate exercise of his right, that is, when he acts with prudence and in good faith, but not when he acts with negligence or abuse.

children.name: Meralco v. Ramos
children.issue: Does MERALCO have the right to immediately disconnect the electric service of the respondents upon discovery of an outside connection attached to their electric meter?
children.ruling: No, Meralco has no right to do so.
children.details: BAD FAITH IS PRESUMED IF THERE IS FAILURE TO COMPLY WITH THE STRICT REQUIREMENTS OF THE LAW THAT PREJUDICES/INJURES ANOTHER

children.name: 8. Tenchavez vs. Escano
children.issue: Are Vicenta’s parents are liable for having dissuaded and discouraged Vicenta from joining her husband?
children.ruling: No. There is no evidence that the parents of Vicenta, out of improper motives, aided and abetted her original suit for annulment, or her subsequent divorce; she appears to have acted independently, and being of age, she was entitled to judge what was best for her and ask that her decisions be respected. Her parents, in so doing, certainly cannot be charged with alienation of affections in the absence of malice or unworthy motives, which have not been shown, good faith being always presumed until the contrary is proved.
children.details: A parent is liable for alienation of affections resulting from his own malicious conduct, as where he wrongfully entices his son or daughter to leave his or her spouse, but he is not liable unless he acts maliciously, without justification and from unworthy motives.

children.name: 9. St Louis Realty vs. CA
children.facts: St. Louis Realty caused to be published with the permission of Arcadio S. Arcadio, but without permission of Doctor Aramil, in the issue of the Sunday Times an advertisement with the heading 'WHERE THE HEART IS'. Below that heading was the photograph of the residence of Doctor Aramil and the Arcadio family where it was portrayed that the house of Doctor Aramil belonged to the latter.
children.issue: Does the wrongful advertisement violate the privacy of private respondent, thus entitling him to damages?
children.ruling: Yes, the private respondent is entitled to damages as the wrongful advertisement violated his privacy. The damages fixed by Judge Leuterio are sanctioned by Articles 2200, 2208 and 2219 of the Civil Code. Article 2219 allows moral damages for acts and actions mentioned in Article 26. As lengthily explained by Justice Gatmaitan, the acts and omissions of the firm fan under Article 26.

children.name: 10. Gregorio v. Court of Appeals
children.facts: the checks and the employee who did not check the address
children.issue: Is the civil suit filed by Gregorio based on quasi-delict or malicious prosecution?
children.ruling: Quasidelict. It appears that Gregorio’s rights to personal dignity, personal security, privacy, and peace of mind were infringed by Sansio and Datuin when they failed to exercise the requisite diligence in determining the identity of the person they should rightfully accuse of tendering insufficiently funded checks. This fault was compounded when they failed to ascertain the correct address of petitioner, thus depriving her of the opportunity to controvert the charges, because she was not given proper notice.
children.details: Article 26 of the Civil Code grants a cause of action for damages, prevention, and other relief in cases of breach, though not necessarily constituting a criminal offense, of the following rights: (1) right to personal dignity; (2) right to personal security; (3) right to family relations; (4) right to social intercourse; (5) right to privacy; and (6) right to peace of mind.

children.name: 11. Capili v. People
children.issue: Is the subsequent declaration of nullity of the second marriage is a ground for dismissal of the criminal case for bigamy?
children.ruling: No, the accused may still be charged with the crime of bigamy, even if there is a subsequent declaration of the nullity of the second marriage, so long as the first marriage was still subsisting when the second marriage was celebrated.
children.details: THE  FINALITY  OF  THE  JUDICIAL  DECLARATION  OF  NULLITY  OF  PETITIONER’S  SECOND MARRIAGE DOES NOT IMPEDE THE FILING OF A CRIMINAL CHARGE FOR BIGAMY AGAINST HIM

children.name: 12. Tenebro v. Court of Appeals
children.issue: Is the subsequent declaration of nullity of the second marriage on the ground of psychological incapacity a ground for acquittal of the accused in a criminal case for bigamy?
children.ruling: No, it is not a ground for acquittal of the accused in a criminal case for bigamy. Article 349 of the Revised Penal Code criminalizes 'any person who shall contract a second or subsequent marriage before the former marriage has been legally dissolved, or before the absent spouse has been declared presumptively dead by means of a judgment rendered in the proper proceedings
children.details: SUBSEQUENT DECLARATION OF NULLITY OF THE SECOND MARRIAGE ON THE GROUND OF PSYCHOLOGICAL INCAPACITY  NOT  A  GROUND  FOR  ACQUITTAL  OF  THE  ACCUSED  IN  A CRIMINAL CASE FOR BIGAMY

children.name: 13. Montañez v. Cipriano
children.issue: Is the judicial nullity of a first marriage prior to the enactment of the Family Code, a valid defense for a charge of bigamy for entering into a second marriage?
children.ruling: NO. Respondent is still liable for bigamy. The elements of the crime of bigamy are: (a) the offender has been legally married; (b) the marriage has not been legally dissolved or, in case his or her spouse is absent, the absent spouse could not yet be presumed dead according to the Civil Code; (c) that he contracts a second or subsequent marriage; and (d) the second or subsequent marriage has all the essential requisites for validity.
children.details: BIGAMY IS CONSUMNATED AT THE MOMENT OF THE CELEBRATION OF THE SECOND MARRIAGE NOTWITHSTANDING THE NULLITY OF THE FIRST MARRIAGE

children.name: 14. San Miguel Properties, Inc., v. Perez
children.details: ACTION FOR SPECIFIC PERFORMANCE, EVEN IF PENDING IN THE HLURB, AND ADMINISTRATIVE AGENCY, RAISES A PREJUDICIAL QUESTION

children.name: 15. Navarro-Banaria v. Banaria
children.facts: 90 year old, not included in bday party

children.name: 17. In the matter of the petition to approve the will of Luz Gaspe Lipson and issuance of letters testamentary
18. Spouses Cabasal vs. BPI Family Savings Bank and Alma De Leon
Marcia v. Cajo
children.details: in relation to Art. 33 and reckless imprudence

children.name: 1. Quimiguing vs. Icao
children.facts: Carmen Quisumbing filed a complaint for support against defendant Icao. In her complaint, she alleged that they were neighbors and had close and confidential relations. Despite Icao being married, he succeeded in having carnal intercourse with plaintiff several times by force and intimidation, and without her consent and as a result she became pregnant, despite efforts and drugs supplied by defendant, and plaintiff had to stop studying. Hence, she claimed support per month, damages and attorneys fees.
children.issue: Does an unborn child have a right to receive support?
children.ruling: Yes. A conceived child, although as yet unborn, is given by law a provisional personality of its own for all purposes favorable to it, as explicitly provided in Article 40 of the Civil Code of the Philippines. The unborn child, therefore, has a right to support from it progenitors, particularly of the defendant-appellee (whose paternity is deemed admitted for the purpose of the motion to dismiss), even if the said child is only 'en ventre de sa mere;' just as a conceived child, even if as yet unborn, may receive donations as prescribed by Article 742 of the same Code, and its being ignored by the parent in his testament may result in preterition of a forced heir that annuls the institution of the testamentary heir, even if such child should be born after the death of the testator (Article 854, Civil Code).
children.details: AN UNBORN CHILD IS GIVEN BY LAW A PROVISIONAL PERSONALITY OF ITS OWN FOR ALL PURPOSES FAVORABLE TO IT

children.name: 2. Geluz v. CA
children.facts: This is a petition for certiorari bringing up for review the question whether the husband of a woman, who voluntarily procured her abortion, could recover damages from the physician who caused the same.
children.issue: Can damages be recovered by the parents on behalf of an unborn child who was aborted on account of the injuries it suffered?
children.ruling: No, no transmission to anyone can take place as the child lacked juridical personality due to its pre-natal death. Since an action for pecuniary damages on account of personal injury or death pertains primarily to the one injured, it is easy to see that if no action for such damages could be instituted on behalf of the unborn child on account of the injuries it received, no such right of action could derivatively accrue to its parents or heirs.
children.significance: representation of parents for the damage or injury
children.details: NO ACTION FOR DAMAGES COULD BE INSTITUTED ON BEHALF OF THE UNBORN CHILD

children.name: 3. Limjoco vs. Estate of Pedro Fragante
children.issue: Is the estate of a decedent considered as a ‘person” in law?
children.ruling: Yes. The estate of a decedent is a person in legal contemplation of law.
children.details: THE ESTATE OF A DECEDENT IS IN LAW REGARDED AS A PERSON AND MAY PROSECUTE AN UNFINISHED ACTION OF THE DECEDENT TO ITS FINAL CONCLUSION

children.name: 4. Moy Ya Lim Yao vs. CID
children.issue: Can Lau Yuen Yueng claim Filipino citizenship by virtue of her marriage with a Filipino?
children.ruling: Yes. Under Section 15 of Commonwealth Act 473, an alien woman marrying a Filipino, native born or naturalized, becomes ipso facto a Filipina provided she is not disqualified to be a citizen of the Philippines under Section 4 of the same law. Likewise, an alien woman married to an alien who is subsequently naturalized here follows the Philippine citizenship of her husband the moment he takes his oath as Filipino citizen, provided that she does not suffer from any of the disqualifications under said Section 4.
children.details: AN ALIEN WOMAN MARRYING A FILIPNO BECOMES IPSO FACTO A FILIPINA PROVIDED SHE IS NOT DISQUALIFIED TO BE A CITIZEN UNDER SECTION 4 OF CA 473

children.name: 5. Republic v. Batuigas
children.facts: Azucena filed a Petition for Naturalization before RTC of Zamboanga del Sur. Azucena alleged in her petition that she has all the qualifications required under Sec. 2 and none of the disqualifications in CA 473. The OSG filed its Motion to Dismiss on the ground that Azucena failed to allege that she engaged in a lawful occupation or in some known lucrative trade, which the RTC later denied.
children.issue: Did Azucena fail to comply with CA 473 as to the income and public hearing requirement?
children.ruling: No. Azucena complied with the income and public hearing requirement. Under existing laws, an alien may acquire citizenship through judicial or administrative naturalization. A third option called derivative naturalization, which is available to alien women married to a Filipino is found under Sec. 15 of CA 473 which provides that “any woman who is now married to a citizen of the Philippines and who might herself be lawfully naturalized shall be deemed a citizen of the Philippines.
children.details: DENIAL OF APPLICATION FOR DERIVATIVE NATURALIZATION NOT A BAR FOR APPLICATION FOR JUDICIAL NATURALIZATION

children.name: 6. Frivaldo vs. COMELEC
children.issue: Was the repatriation of Frivaldo valid and legal, thus seasonably cure his lack of citizenship as to qualify him to be proclaimed and to hold the Office of Governor?
children.ruling: Yes, the repatriation of Frivaldo retroacted to the date of the filing of his application on August 17, 1994.
children.details: Under the Civil Code of the Philippines, laws shall have no retroactive effect, unless the contrary is provided. But there are settled exceptions to this general rule, such as when the statute is CURATIVE or REMEDIAL in nature or when it CREATES NEW RIGHTS. A reading of P.D. 725 immediately shows that it creates a new right, and also provides for a new remedy, thereby filling certain voids in our laws. Said statute also provided a new remedy and a new right in favor of other natural born Filipinos who (had) lost their Philippine citizenship but now desire to re-acquire Philippine citizenship, because prior to the promulgation of P.D. 725 such former Filipinos would have had to undergo the tedious and cumbersome process of naturalization, but with the advent of P.D. 725 they could now re-acquire their Philippine citizenship under the simplified procedure of repatriation.

children.name: 7. Romualdez-Marcos vs. COMELEC
children.issue: Is petitioner a resident, for election purposes, of the First District of Leyte for a period of one year at the time of the May 9, 1995 elections?
children.ruling: Yes. Petitioner is a resident, for election purposes, of the First District of Leyte.
children.details: UNDER THE CIVIL CODE, THERE IS DISTINCTION BETWEEN DOMICILE AND RESIDENCE; FOR PURPOSES OF POLITICAL LAW, RESIDENCE IS USED SYNONYMOUSLY WITH DOMICILE

children.name: Module 2
children.enum1: I.Requisites of Marriage FC Arts. 1-34
children.enum2: II. Void Marriages

Module 3
children.enum1: I. Voidable Marriages (Arts. 45-54, FC)
children.enum2: II. Legal Separation (Arts. 55-67, FC)

children.name: Class Notes
children.details: 1-67, Family Code
children.enum1: Falcis
children.enum2: Pulido
children.enum4: People v. Aragon - you cannot raise the defense of nullity of a previous case against the crime of bigamy. NOTE - there is a case (pulido) which might change the rules as to prejudicial questions on bigamy.
children.enum5: Quiz: Common law marriages made by mere agreement do not have marriage ceremonies and therefore are not recognized in the philippines between Filipinos even though in a foreign country
children.enum6: Motivation to enter into a marriage, as long as the essential and formal elements of marriage are present, does not affect the validity of marriage.
children.enum7: Silverio - transgender not allowed to change sex - female sex is that which produces the ova.

children.name: page 2
children.details: Cagandahan - allowed an intersex to change entries in birth certificate
children.enum1: Application for marriage license. Parental consent will not void the marriage license, but it is voidable at the instance of the parent or the minor whose parental consent was not obtained 5 years from reaching the age of 21.
children.enum2: Defect in the essential requisites - voidable (refers only to the essential element of consent. But it does not apply to legal capacity. Minority is not cured to make the marriage valid.
children.enum3: Authority of the solemnizing officer as to the elements -  Art. 7 incumbent member of the judiciary (within his territorial jurisdiction) -
children.enum4: What if one of the requisites for the authority of a solemnizing officer is absent - is it an irregularity? or is it absence? ->
children.enum5: Delson -> Irregularity of Formal Requisites are only present in Marriage Ceremony and Marriage License, and Not in the Authority of the Solemnizing Officer
children.enum6: Art. 35 par. 2 provides an exception (Good Faith Marriages)
children.enum7: Witnesses in a Marriage Ceremony - absence of one witness -> only an irregularity
children.enum8: Navarro v. Domagtoy - a case against a judge, an obiter, but provides that lack of jurisdiction of the solemnizing officer is only an irregularity

children.name: page 3
children.enum1: Falcis Case
children.enum2: Concept of Marriage is facing some challenges (same sex marriage, absolute divorce)

children.name: Same Sex
children.details: 2015 US - Hodges v. Obergefell - cause of action: the nonadopting surviving spouse and the adopter are complete strangers; basis of case: due process and equal protection
children.enum1: 14th amendment to guarantees the right to marry whomsoever one chooses
children.enum2: Facial Challenge was not a proper action. The petitioner should have filed the case 'as applied' to his situation. Comment of the SolGen - an intervenor was attempted to be introduced. Unfortunately, the court did not allow since there was no remedy prayed for
children.enum3: graduate school paper of Dean - LGBT needs protection. Property regimes of LGBT couples need to be regulated or protected by law

children.name: Absolute Divorce
children.details: Philippines do not recognize absolute divorce, but only relative divorce.
children.enum1: Estaves v. Escano, Lavadia v. Heirs of Luna
children.enum2: Van Dorn, Ibay-Somera - valid effects of divorce obtained abroad
children.enum3: Art. 26 [2] - new law -> new interpretation -> validly obtained divorce decree need not be initiated by the alien spouse -> not against public policy because there is a distinction as to the application only to 'mixed marriages'
children.enum4: Corpus v. Sto. Tomas - what is the remedy? there is distinction between petition for recognition of foreign judgment and petition under Rule 108 (correction of entries in the civil registry)
children.enum6: Manalo v. Republic (both petitions are filed)
children.enum7: Racho Tanaka, Kondo (japanese parties) - Divorce by Mutual Agreement
children.enum8: Areza - on proof of foreign law

children.name: Bills on Absolute Divorce
children.details: Committee on the house already passed it. The bill's grounds on divorce originate from the FC's grounds on legal separation, void, voidable
children.enum1: Canon 1095 - Rule that Governs marriage in the Roman Catholic Church - lack of reason, lack of discretion, failure to comply with the obligations of marriage
children.enum2: Tan v. Andal - did it change the interpretation of Art. 36? - a reiteration of previous jurisprudence (Kalaw v. Fernandez, Ngote v. Ngote) but a clear modification of the Molina guidelines

children.name: Molina Guidelines
children.enum1: Tan v. Andal - quantum of evidence - more than preponderance but less than beyond reasonable doubt = Clear and Convincing Evidence (due to the presumption of validity of marriage)
children.enum2: A petitioner may invoke his own incapacity to annul the marriage
children.enum3: Tan v. Andal (Old) Root cause of the Psychological incapacity has to be medically identified must be sufficienclty proven by experts (New) Psychological Incapacity is not a medical or psychological incapacity - it is a legal concept. It is the judge that determines the existence of psychological incapacity.
children.enum4: Tan v. Andal - Does not prohibit or discourage the findings and proof of psychological/personality disorders, but only prevents judges from automatically striking down a petition for noncompliance with the Molina Guidelines
children.enum5: Incurability - means legal incurability - persistent incapacity with respect to a specific partner
children.enum6: Gravity - does not refer to dangers of the illness
children.enum7: Not all failure to comply with parental obligations will result to psychological incapacity - (only greivous such as sexual abuse to the child)
children.enum8: Tan Andal - Art. 36 will also include the lack of discretion under Art. 1095(2)

children.name: Consequences
children.details: Will the parties adversely affected by the Molina Doctrine be able to refile their case?
children.enum1: No.

children.name: Petitions for Declaraction of Nullity
children.enum1: Will AM 2-11-10 apply to cases of recognition of a foreign divorce? No. (Marinay Fujiki)
children.enum2: The rules only apply to marriages solemnized within the effectivity of the Family Code. -> Rules are prospective, except when the law provides
children.enum3: Does not apply to marriages solemnized under the Family Code but before March 4, 2003 (effectivity of the Rule)
children.enum4: Republic v. Olaybar - The Rule also does not apply to a case where there is no marriage at all. Rule 108 is sufficient as a remedy.
children.enum5: While the spouses are still alive, only the husband and wife can file the petition. The rights of the heirs are inchoate.
children.enum6: Huliano Llave case, Tamano - The first spouse in a case for bigamy may file a case for the annulment of the marriage, but it does not preclude the filing of the 2nd innocent spouse.
children.enum7: Where to File: Rule on Venue (Adm. Matter 63 series of 2019) - Documentary Requirements and Sworn Declaration by the Lawyer showing proof that the petitioner is a bona fide resident of the place.
children.enum8: Dio v. Dio - Property Regimes Note: Decision is different from the Decree. Only upon compliance of the requirements (liquidation of the property regime) will the decree be issued. under 45, under 40

children.name: You need to fix this note... sir too fast
children.details: A petition for partition can be filed through another petition under the Civil Code
children.enum1: If the case was made under Art. 36, no need to comply with Art. 51
children.enum2: Art. 40

children.name: Common Law Spouses - Ninal Bayadog
children.details: There are exceptions to the rule requiring a marriage license. Policy: the law prefers couples to be married. To insulate live ins (cohabiting couples) from shame of not being married
children.enum1: Judge Necessario - judge was disciplined.

children.name: Busuego v. Office of the Ombudsman
III. Rights and Obligations between Husband and Wife
Obligation to Live Together
children.enum1: Exception: The court may exempt one spouse from living with the other if:
children.enum2: (1) the other should live abroad; and
children.enum3: (2) if there is valid and compelling reason

children.name: Reminders:
children.enum1: 1. The court is powerless to enforce such obligation.
children.enum2: 2. But if a spouse leaves the conjugal dweling without just cause and later demands legal support, the other spouse has the option of giving support by receiving and maintaining him/her in the family dwelling and if he/she refuses, the right to receive legal support terminates
children.enum3: 3. But if the wife left the conjugal home because of a valid and justifiable reason, she is entitled to separate maintenance

children.name: Obligation to Observe Mutual Love, Respect, and Fidelity
children.enum1: Reminders:
children.enum2: 1. The court is likewise powerless to enforce this obligation
children.enum3: 2. But there are sanctions for non-observance of this obligation, such as criminal prosecutions for adultery, concubinage, bigamy, etc

children.name: Obligation to Render Mutual Help and Support
children.enum1: Reminders:
children.enum2: 1. It is the obligation of mutual support which can be enforced through legal action.
children.enum3: 2. The fact that it was not the husband who called for medical assistance for the wife, he is liable to pay the expenses incurred in relation thereto and not his in-laws

children.name: Choice of Family Domicile
children.enum1: The right to choose the family domicile belongs to both the husband and the wife. In case of disagreement, the court shall decide.

children.name: Exemption:
children.details: The court may exempt one spouse from living with the other if:
children.enum1: 1. The other should live abroad
children.enum2: 2. If there is a valid and compelling reason.
children.enum4: However, the court is powerless to enforce the obligation to live together. But once the court exempts one of the spouses from living with the other, the latter shall not lose the right to demand legal support from the other spouse

children.name: When Exemption Does not Apply
children.enum1: If the same is not compatible with the solidarity of the family

children.name: Execise of Profession, Business, or Activity
children.enum1: Under RA 9262, if the husband prevents his wife from engaging in any legitimate profession, occupation, business, or activity, he has committed an act of violence punishable by the said law, except in cases where the husband objects on valid, serious, and moral grounds.

children.name: Liability for Obligations Incurred in Case of Objection
children.details: If the court finds that such objection is proper, the resulting liability shall be born by the following:
children.enum1: * Benefit Accrued to the Family Prior to the Objection => Chargable to AC or CP
children.enum2: * Benefit Accrued to the Family After the Objection => Enforced against SP of the spouse who has not obtained consent
children.enum3: * No benefit accured => Enforced against SP of the spouse who has not obtained consent
